doc.after: Angkor Wat, located at 13Â°24â²45â³N 103Â°52â²0â³Eï»¿ / ï»¿13.41250Â°N 103.86667Â°Eï»¿ / 13.41250; 103.86667, is a unique combination of the temple mountain, the standard design for the empire's state temples and the later plan of concentric galleries. The temple is a representation of Mount Meru, the home of the gods: the central quincunx of towers symbolises the five peaks of the mountain, and the walls and moat the surrounding mountain ranges and ocean.[17] Access to the upper areas of the temple was progressively more exclusive, with the laity being admitted only to the lowest level.[18]
